turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: So, you doing anything tonight?

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: Working.

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: Hmm, how about tomorrow night?

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: Working.

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: Night after that?

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: Look, you're a nice guy, but I'm not really dating right now.

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: I'm not that good at 'no,' Liza.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: Too bad.  Because I'm terrible at 'yes.'

turns.speaker: LAWYER
turns.text: Liza, settle a bet for us.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: What do I look like to you? Switzerland?

turns.speaker: OPERATOR
turns.text: Federal Bureau of Investigation.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: I need to speak with an Agent Lowry.

turns.speaker: OPERATOR
turns.text: The office is closed for the evening. Is this an emergency?

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: Do you <u>have</u> an Agent Lowry in your New York office?

turns.speaker: OPERATOR
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: Then this is a goddamn emergency.

turns.speaker: OPERATOR
turns.text: Go ahead, Miss Sutton.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: Agent Lowry?

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Ah, your psychotic is here.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: Not today...

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: Tell him I'm on vacation.  That I won't be back for two weeks.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I don't know if you're the best lawyer I've got or a high school sophomore.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I've been given a cease and desist on all matters relating to Jerry Fletcher.  We're not to discuss him with the press, the N.Y.P.D., anyone.  Building police are to arrest him on sight and we're to report any attempt he makes to contact you.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: This doesn't make sense.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: It makes perfect sense.  Field work is not our oeuvre.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: I don't like it.  Something's wrong.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: Dr. Jonas thought you might be inclined not to cooperate.  Why is that?

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: We don't know who Jonas is.  We don't know who it is we're cooperating with.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: I've had a lot of credentials flashed in my face, Liza.  What I saw yesterday, I know not to ask questions.  We're out.  Shut off. Terminated.  <u>Understood</u>?

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: -- Understood.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: Go to the northeast corner.  Call a cab.  Bring the pizza.  Then there's a poem.  Roses are red, violets are blue, if the Pope goes to Washington, I would, too.

turns.speaker: WILSON
turns.text: What the hell does that mean?

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: We're waiting for jurisdictional problems to be cleared up.  This guy Fletcher's something else.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: Tell me about it.

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: While we walk.  D.C. police want him for assault. Secret Service for counterfeiting and we're tracking him on a string of bank robberies.  No one knows what the C.I.A. wants him for.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: Wait --

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: Guy's a C.I.A. shrink.  Here to I.D. Fletcher.  They knew each other somehow.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: You don't understand --

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: Which way did he go?

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: I don't know.  Didn't see him.

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: That's the book Hinkley had on him when he shot Reagan.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: I was just thinking that.

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: You're welcome!  Spooks.  So, you want to compare notes on this guy.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: No.  Not yet.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: Agent Lowry.

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: Wasn't my idea.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: Jonas?

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: It's his show for now.  Look, you want to get some dinner?  Inter- Agency cooperation and all?

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: When I'm ready to compare notes, I'll let you know.

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: Your call.  Have a good night.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: Can I talk to you a second?

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: Go ahead.  We'll be right down.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: Do you believe me?

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: Yeah, I do.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: I want to believe you, too.

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: Who's the Deputy Director of the F.B.I.?

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: You think we have time to fool around like this?  Come on.

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: What gave me away?

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: Nothing.  I was just making sure. So, who are you?

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: I'm, it really doesn't matter. Think C.I.A. and exponentiate. I'm a government employee and I've been watching Jerry for awhile.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: And Jonas?

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: He's why I watch Jerry.  Jerry's the bait for Jonas.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: He's shown himself.  Why haven't you arrested him or killed him or done whatever it is you do?

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: Jonas builds assassins for a living.  Several of whom may be in place already.  We'd like to kill a few birds with one stone.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: Where do you think Jerry is?

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: No idea.  Honest.  What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: I'm going to find him.  Because he'd find me.

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: Don't go home.  And don't go to work.  Either one could be bad.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: What do you suggest?

turns.speaker: LOWRY
turns.text: That you come with me.

turns.speaker: LIZA
turns.text: I don't think so.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: A.T.L.
turns.text: I'm not sure.  We have no launch protocol; the entry of the passenger is supposed to initiate activation.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Anything happening in there, El?

turns.speaker: A.T.L.
turns.text: We have benzel activation, repeat, we have benzel activation.  Control to Arroway, you okay in there?  Repeat, Control to Arroway, come back.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Ellie?

turns.speaker: A.T.L.
turns.text: We've lost contact.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: Pull the plug.  Get her out of there.

turns.speaker: A.T.L.
turns.text: There's no plug to pull.

turns.speaker: PETER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: A.T.L.
turns.text: There is no abort procedure -- we don't know how we turned the damn thing on, let alone how to turn it off.

turns.speaker: CHAIRMAN
turns.text: ... And this is how the extraterrestrial presented himself to you?  As your father?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: CHAIRMAN
turns.text: He died...  ... in 1972.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: CHAIRMAN
turns.text: Dr. Arroway, do you think it's possible you had some kind of... delusional episode.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Is it possible...?

turns.speaker: CHAIRMAN
turns.text: All the elements are there.  A woman, orphaned young, under a great deal of stress.  The failure of a project she's staked her self-worth and very sense of identity on -- induces a fantasy of reuniting with her 'father in heaven' as it were. Is it possible?

turns.speaker: CHAIRMAN
turns.text: You don't believe it to be... tell me something, Doctor.  Why do you think they would go to all this trouble... bring you tens of thousands of light years, and then send you home without a shred of proof?  Sort of bad form, wouldn't you say?  What was their intent?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I don't know.  Ultimately their motives may be as incomprehensible as their technology.

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: Dr. Arroway --

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Michael Kitz, National Security Advisor.

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: Dr. Arroway, let me first say --

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Mike, because of the Earth's rotation we're only in line with Vega so many hours a day; the only way to get the whole message is to cooperate with other stations.  If Dr. Arroway hadn't moved quickly we could have lost key elements.

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: Okay, fine, they've got the primes -- but if you're right about there being another more significant transmission still to come --

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Hope there's a cartoon.

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: How is that possible?  How could all that information be encoded in --

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: What in the hell...?

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: It's a hoax.  I knew it!

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: -- Or 'you're our kind of people --'

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: -- It's extremely unlikely that they had any idea what they were looking at.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Now I remember why I went into theoretical work.  Kent.

turns.speaker: KENT
turns.text: Glad to have you, David.  How's the new office?

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Still settling in, really.  Where's Dr. Arroway?

turns.speaker: KENT
turns.text: Nothing.  Okay.  Some of us have been a little... not concerned, exactly, but...

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Tell me.

turns.speaker: KENT
turns.text: Last week, about 3 A.M., Fish -- Dr. Fisher -- was on a late shift, and he found her doing laundry.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: KENT
turns.text: So... there wasn't any clothes in the machine.  She was just sitting there on the floor with her ear pressed up against the Maytag. Listening.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: I'm sorry, Miss Arroway, not only is it too Speculative a subject for a doctoral dissertation, at this point in your career it'd be tantamount to suicide.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'm willing to take that risk.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: I'm not.  You're far too promising a scientist to waste your considerable gifts on this nonsense --

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Dr. Drumlin, we are talking about what could potentially be the most important discovery in the history of humanity.  There are over four hundred billion stars out there --

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: And only two probabilities:  One: there is intelligent life in the universe but they're so far away you'll never contact it in your lifetime --

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You're --

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Two:  There's nothing out there but noble gasses and carbon compounds and you'd be wasting your time.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What if you're wrong?  No -- I'll grant you probabilities but as a scientist without all the evidence -- you can't deny the possibility -- and I believe even the remotest possibility of something this profoundly... profound is worth investigation -- and worth taking a few risks.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: I disagree.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Then disagree but don't stand in my way!

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Pepsi?  Tequila?

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: No, thanks.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Peter sends his regards.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Oh?  How's he doing?

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Very well; since my appointment he's been made interim director.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Really?  Congratulations, by the way.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: I'm surprised you even knew it was an election year.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: 'President's Science Advisor' -- so what, you just spend all your time jetting around on Air Force One now...?

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Now exactly.  It's... complicated.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: No doubt.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Ellie...

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Did I tell you we've expanded the search spectrum?  We're including several other possible magic frequencies -- not just the hydrogen line anymore.  I was trying to get inside their heads, y'know?  And I started thinking, what other constants are there in the Universe besides hydrogen, and then suddenly it was so obvious -- transcendantals, right?  So we've been trying variations of pi...

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: You know why I'm here.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It's not enough having my search time systematically cut down -- you know I'm down to three hours a week now.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Ellie, I should have done this a long time ago, certainly before I left the N.S.F., but I wanted to give you every benefit of the doubt --

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You can't just pull the plug, David.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: It's not like you've given me much choice.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Meaning...

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Meaning I have to go defend a budget to the President and to Congress and you're out here listening to washing machines.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'm searching for patterns in the noise, that's all.  Order in the chaos.  I'm practicing listening --

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: The point is, this isn't just scientific inquiry anymore -- it's turned into some kind of personal obsession.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: The difference being what -- that I refuse to adopt the standard line, that I don't care about the results of my work?  Well, I do care.  Of course any discovery has to be verifiable, of course it must be subject to all rigors of scientific method, but I refuse to go around pretending I'm some kind of dispassionate automaton when it's obvious to anyone with a brain I'm just not.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: No... You're not.  But the price has just gotten too high.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Goddamnit, they are out there, David --

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Then why haven't you detected any signals?  If, as you claim, there have been thousands, millions of advanced civilizations out there for millions of years then why hasn't one signal gotten through?  It'll take a month or two for the paperwork to go through; you're welcome to stay until then.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: David --

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: It was a worthy experiment -- worthy of you; I was wrong about that part. But it's over now.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Mathematics is the only truly universal language, Senator.  We think this may be a beacon -- an announcement to get our attention.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: If it's attention you want I'd say you've got it.  Just one thing:  Why Vega? Everyone's looked at Vega for years with no results, and now, yesterday, they start broadcasting primes. Why?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It's hardly yesterday; the signal's been traveling for over twenty-six years.  As for why...  I'm hoping your own expertise in decryption algorithms will help us find out -- to see if there's another message buried deeper in the signal.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: ... could it be a nested code of some sort?

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: You must have checked the signal for polarization modulation already...

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Throw a gray scale on it; standard interpolation.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Rotate 90 degrees counterclock wise.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: ... Arrangements also have to be made for the V.I.P.s coming in, mostly religious leaders...

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What?  Why?

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: The theological ramifications of all this are obvious; the President feels we need to include religious interests rather than alienate them. She's also named Palmer Joss as their liaison; he's requested a meeting with you.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: With me.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Apparently he's genuinely interested in science.  This could be a chance to win him over.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'm going to convert Mr. Science-is- the-root-of-all-evil?  This is absurd, David.  We have work to do here, I don't have time to play babysitter to the God Squad.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Ellie --

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: I want you to listen to me, carefully.  The minute the implications of this message became clear, this stopped being simply a scientific matter and became a political one -- an extremely complex, extremely volatile one. There are forces at work here you don't understand; I can help you up to a point, but only up to a point.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Are you threatening me?

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: It's not a threat, Ellie, it's a fact -- if you're not careful, you may find yourself out in the cold very quickly.  Play ball.  Really. It's good advice.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Ms. President, this is communist paranoia right out of War of the Worlds.  There is no reason whatsoever to believe the ETIs intentions are hostile.  We pose no threat to them -- it would be like us going out of our way to destroy microbes on a beach in Africa.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Interesting analogy.  And how guilty would we feel if we happened to destroy some microbes on a beach in Africa?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What is it?  What's happened?

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: We've cracked it.  Lunacharsky found it.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You mean --

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: You were right, Ellie.  You were right all along.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: David --

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Ellie.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Do you have a minute -- ?

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Actually I'm running late --

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It'll just take a moment.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: David... I know we've had our differences... but I've always thought of you as a fair man, even when we've disagreed -- and It's in that light I'm hoping you'll consider my request...

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: I don't understand.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'm asking for your help, David.  I want to go.  They'll need someone relatively young, unattached -- and probably a scientist.  As the President's Science Advisor you have enormous weight... I'm asking if you'll support my candidacy.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Ellie... you should know that I'm no longer the President's Science Advisor.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: As of three o'clock this afternoon. I submitted my resignation.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You...

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Excuse me, I'm late for a meeting.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: ... Two years is still a hell of a long time -- and as far as we can tell there aren't any provisions in the machine design for storing food, water, even air...

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: ... I can't believe they wouldn't take something as basic as our biological needs into account...

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: They knew our level of development. If, as you say, they've done this many times they'd be well aware of the implications.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Maybe they are.  Maybe this is all part of the package.  The building of the machine has demanded international cooperation on an unprecedented scale.  Maybe requiring us to come together in this way was, in effect, part of the plan.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: You aren't staying?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: This... seemed best.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Right.  Well.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Good luck, David.

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Ellie... we both know that if I was any kind of a man, I never would've entered this race.  That I would have told the President straight out:  Helen, Eleanor Arroway is naive and strident and an enormous pain in the ass... but she's got more courage and intelligence than the rest of us put together.  That more then anyone else on the planet, she's earned this.  And that she should be the one to go because she's the best we have.  But that's not who I am.  I like to think it's who I might've been if things had gone a different way; that I might have been worthy, really worthy of what I've been given...  You do what you have to do.  And in the end, as with everything, it comes down to power.  And it isn't fair...

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What would you have me say, David?

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: Nothing.  I guess I just wanted to thank you.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Thank you?

turns.speaker: DRUMLIN
turns.text: For giving me a chance, just for a moment, to feel what it must be like to be you.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT LASKER
turns.text: What does it say?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It could be anything.  The first volume of some Encyclopedia Galactica...

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Because you cut it from the budget three years running.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT LASKER
turns.text: How soon will you be able to decode it?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: ... And while its function remains, for the moment, a mystery, my best guess is that it represents a transport of some kind.

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT LASKER
turns.text: A transport.  So are they coming or are we going?

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT LASKER
turns.text: Mr. Rank's organization represents the point of view of tens of millions of families, Dr. Arroway. Feel free to disagree, but there won't be any suppressing of opinions here today.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Yes -- of course -- all I'm saying is, this message was written in the language of science -- mathematics -- and was clearly intended to be received by scientists.  If it had been religious in nature it should have taken the form of a burning bush, or a booming voice from the sky...

turns.speaker: PRESIDENT LASKER
turns.text: What's the status of the decryption effort?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Well --

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Dr. Lunacharsky...?

turns.speaker: LUNACHARSKY
turns.text: Analyzing signal polarization shifts.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What...

turns.speaker: LUNACHARSKY
turns.text: In ancient times when parchment was in short supply people would write over old writing... it was called a palimpsest.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: A third layer.

turns.speaker: LUNACHARSKY
turns.text: There's no way of knowing.  Without a key -- a primer, to help us, maybe never.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Maybe it'll be at the end of the data when the message recycles.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: LUNACHARSKY
turns.text: We've repeated.  A few minutes ago the message cycled back to page one.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: And?

turns.speaker: LUNACHARSKY
turns.text: No primer.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: How can that be?

turns.speaker: LUNACHARSKY
turns.text: I don't know.  Maybe there is a fourth layer in there somewhere, but if there is, I sure as hell can't find it.

turns.speaker: WILLIE
turns.text: Been there, done that, got the T-shirt.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: VB10's an M dwarf; Signa Draconis... too old.

turns.speaker: WILLIE
turns.text: Got a bogey, boss?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I'm not sure.  You mind checking right ascension 18 hours, 34 minutes; declination plus 38 degrees 41 minutes?

turns.speaker: WILLIE
turns.text: Hydrogen times pi...  Got it.  Strong sucker.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Put it on speakers.

turns.speaker: WILLIE
turns.text: That can't be right; it's only twenty-six light years away.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I scanned it at Arecibo; negative results, always.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: How's the spying tonight, guys?

turns.speaker: WILLIE
turns.text: NORAD's not tracking any spacecraft in our vector including snoops; shuttle Endeavor's in sleep mode.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Dr. Cullers?

turns.speaker: KENT
turns.text: Kent, Kent for Chrissakes.  You must be Eleanor.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Ellie.  Pulsar?

turns.speaker: KENT
turns.text: 1919+21.  Found a glitch in the timing; probably a starquake.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Nice.  Where?

turns.speaker: KENT
turns.text: Here, right around Centaurus A.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: This is how you see the sky?

turns.speaker: KENT
turns.text: It's how I hear it.  The display's just a little something I programmed for astronomers with the misfortune of sight.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It's beautiful.

turns.speaker: KENT
turns.text: Never seen the optical sky myself, but I hear it's nice too.

turns.speaker: KENT
turns.text: You've only searched -- what is it, sixteen hundred stars without a peep?  Try not to take it too personally.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Thank you, Mr. Sensitive.  I'm coming at this wrong... missing something... something...

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Okay, let's just slow down.  Pull up the starfield signal origin.

turns.speaker: KENT
turns.text: It can't be coming from Vega, the system's too young.

turns.speaker: KENT
turns.text: Can't we get rid of them?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It's a civilian facility.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I think we just hit the cosmic jackpot.

turns.speaker: KENT
turns.text: It's incredibly rich.  We've been cataloging it in frames or 'pages'; right now we're on 10,413.

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: I'll come right to the point, Doctor.  Your sending this message all over the world may well be a breach of National Security.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: This isn't a person to person call, Mr. Kitz.  I don't really think the civilization sending the message intended it just for Americans.

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: I'm saying you might have consulted us; the contents of this message could be extremely sensitive...

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You want to classify prime numbers?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: -- which we'll also need the network's help to receive and decode!

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: You don't seem to understand that it's your interests I'm trying to protect -- !

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: Colonel Jarrod, I'd like a twenty mile radio-silent perimeter put around this installation immediately.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: And a hundred mile airspace.

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: And a hundred mile airspace.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Pardon me, but you can't do -- !

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: If at some later date the message proves harmless, we can discuss sharing it with the rest of the world, but until then --

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: That's terrific, but there's one problem:  we don't have the means to receive all the data on our own.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: ... I don't understand it.  All I can think is that maybe because the video gear wasn't accounted for in the original plans it somehow violated the integrity of the design.

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: Is that your official response?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I don't have an official response, Michael.  All I have are the same questions you have.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: There is no direct evidence, no.

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: And current theory holds that to sustain the sort of wormholes you're talking about, even for a fraction of a second, would require more energy than our sun produces in a year, is that correct?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I don't have the figures in front of me, but yes, that sounds about right.

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: In fact, by all the laws of physics we know what you claim to have experienced is simply impossible.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: By our standards... yes.

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: Please answer the question, Doctor.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Is it possible.  Yes.  But --

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: Thank you, Doctor.  Now --

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: -- but I don't believe it to be the truth.

turns.speaker: KITZ
turns.text: So why don't you admit what by your own standards must be the truth: that this experience simply didn't happen.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Because I can't.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Small moves, Captain, small moves.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I can't move any smaller.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Try again between the static and 'Hey Jude'; that's where they're hiding.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Talk to him.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: But what do I say?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Just be yourself, Captain.  Find out where he is.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Could we hear to China?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: On that old shortwave?  Maybe on a clear night.  Come on now, under the covers.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Could we hear to the moon?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Big enough radio, I don't see why not.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Could we hear God?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Mmm, that's a good one.  Maybe his echo...  Okay, no more stalling.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Okay, okay... there.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Pensacola.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That's a beauty, Captain.  Now get some sleep.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Time to sleep now, Captain.  But you can ask more questions in the morning, okay?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Okay.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I used... I used to dream you were alive... and then I'd wake up and lose you all over again.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: I'm sorry I couldn't be there for you, sweetheart.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Dad... But tell me, how did... I mean how can...?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You're not real.  None of this is.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That's my scientist.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: So.  Are you an hallucination?  Or are little gear trains and circuit boards under your skin?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Am I artifact or dream?  You might ask that about anything.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: But you're so... I mean how could you possibly...?  When I was unconscious.  You... downloaded... my thoughts, my memories, even...  This beach.  I've never been here but I remember... it's how I always imagined...  Pensacola.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: We thought this might make things a little easier.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: So who -- what -- are you?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Originally just another species like yourselves.  Well, not like you at all actually, but...

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Can you show me?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Small moves, Captain, small moves.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why did you contact us?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You contacted us.  We were simply listening.  We've been listening for millions of years.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: And those other docking ports I saw... I mean... there are others?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Many others.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: And they all travel here through this wormhole subway system you built.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Oh, we didn't build it.  The transit system has been in place for billions of years; we're just its... caretakers.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: So who...?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: We don't know.  Whoever they were, they were gone long before we ever got here.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: The scale... it's just...  So all the civilizations you detect; they all end up coming here?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Not all.  Some choose to stay at home and dream their dreams.  Some never make it this far.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: So we passed some kind of test?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You have your mother's hands...  There are no tests, Ellie.  We don't sit in judgment.  Think of us more as... librarians.  Curators of the Universe's rarest and most valuable creation...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: ... life is unspeakably rare.  So whenever we do find another civilization, especially one that's... struggling... We send a message.  Sometimes we can offer help.  Sometimes we can't.  But we always try.  Life is simply too precious not to.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Can you help us?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Am I one... or many?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: The librarian... or the library...?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: ... all those voices... you gather them all together.  Millions of intelligences in one consciousness... and now we're a part of it.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: You always have been.  We're all descendants of the same stars, Ellie.  All made of the same primordial atoms.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: So.  What happens now?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Now... you go home.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: No!  I mean... why so soon?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: If we don't engineer a consistent causality it'll work itself out on its own, and that's almost always worse.  Ellie, according to your physics none of this is possible.  A lot of it you're simply not capable of understanding, not yet.  No offense.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: None taken... but ... do we get to come back?  Others of my kind, I mean.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Eventually you'll get here on your own.  This was just the first step; in time you'll take another.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: But -- other people from our planet should see what I've seen -- they should witness this for themselves.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: That isn't the way it works.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: But you said you wanted to help -- don't you see what it would mean?

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: No more stalling, Captain.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Please -- if you... downloaded... everything about us you know the problems we face, the impact it could have -- it could make the difference --

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Ellie... this is the way it's been done for billions of years...

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: It's time to go home now.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: No.  Please.

turns.speaker: TED
turns.text: Childhood is over, Ellie.  It's time to grow up.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: S.R. Hadden...  You compromised our security codes.

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: Once upon a time I was a hell of an engineer.  Please, sit, Doctor.  I have guests so rarely, it's important to me they feel welcome in my home.  Did you know this was once Yeltsin's flying dascha?  That dent is where he threw a bottle of vodka at the pilot.  At least that's what the people who sold me the plane said...

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You live here.

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: I find it convenient to keep my interests... mobile.  Anyway, I've had my fill of life on the ground. After spending much of this century pursuing the evils and pleasures the world has to offer -- after outliving three wives and two children...  I find I've had quite enough of planet Earth.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Why am I here, Mr. Hadden?

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: The infamous, unfashionable bluntness.  You're here so we can do business. I want to make a deal.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What kind of deal?

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: The powers that be have been quite busy lately, falling over each other to position themselves for the game of the century, if not the millennium.  Perhaps you've noticed.  Perhaps I could help deal you back in.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: I didn't realize I was out.

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: Oh, maybe not out -- but definitely looking for you coat.  I understand you've had some difficulty locating the -- what are you calling it?  The 'primer' that will make decryption possible...  I've found it.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You've... found it.  What could I possibly have that you would want, Mr. Hadden?

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: I've had a long time to make enemies, Dr. Arroway.  There are many governments, business interests, even religious leaders who would like to see me disappear. And I will grant them their wish soon enough... But before I do, I wish to make a small contribution -- a final gesture of goodwill toward the people of this little planet who've given -- from whom I've taken so much.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: If I knew you any better I'd say that doesn't sound like you.

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: That's my girl...  Lights.

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: Page after page of data -- over sixty-three thousand in all, if I'm not mistaken... and at the end of each...

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: A page-break signal.  A period.

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: Not if you think like a Vegan.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You're saying... there is no separate primer in the message -- because it's on every page so the recipient can decipher it wherever he is --

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: -- even if he doesn't receive the entire transmission.  Heaven is the mustard seed.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Some kind of circuitry...?

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: Very good, Doctor.  I've also detected structural elements, back references, a general movement from the simple to the complex -- all of which would seem to indicate instructions -- an enormously complicated set of instructions -- for building something.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: A machine.  But a machine that does what?

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: That would seem to be the question of the hour.  I want to build it, Doctor.  Of course I'm already lobbying through the usual channels of influence and corruption -- but as I said, my colorful past has made many of those channels... difficult to navigate. I need someone on the inside.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: And in return?

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: In return... you get the primer -- and with it the power to stay in the game.  Do we have a deal?

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: Mr. Hadden, I'm a scientist; I don't make deals... But.  If you wish to give me, in good faith, access to your information, I can assure you that I will exert all reasonable efforts to promote your cause wherever it doesn't conflict with the best interests of science... or my better judgment.

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: That's my girl.  Done.

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: A sunrise and a sunset every forty- five minutes.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It's so... small.

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: Poor, tired, spinning girl... How we feasted on her.  And now that we've had our fill and given her a giant dose of the clap... we're pulling out.  That's Paris, where my daughter was born.  Moscow, where gangsters rule the night and I gave up smoking.  So many battles, so many lives... all that sturm, and drang.  As if it never happened.  If it weren't for a few power grids, you wouldn't know we existed.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What's that?

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: Japanese squid fleet.  They use lights to attract them to the surface... then turn them into sushi.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: It looks like pixie dust...  Kent would've given anything to see this.  David, too.

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: Yes.  A shame.  Still... it'd be worse if they died for nothing.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: What are you talking about?  It's over.

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: Oh, not quite yet.  At least for their sake...  ... I hope it's not.  Because they're running out of time.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: You sound like Joseph.  You think the world ends with the millennium?

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: I think whoever sent the message did it because they're worried about us.

turns.speaker: ELLIE
turns.text: The gods sent us the machine because they took pity on us.

turns.speaker: HADDEN
turns.text: Wouldn't you if you saw Hitler on TV?  Come; I want to show you something.
